fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Function
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.8

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let X and Y be sets. We define a Function from X to Y to be a relation of X and Y denoted f\colon X\to Y such that:
Total: \mathop {\textrm {dom}}\nolimits (f)=X, and
Function-like: for all objects x, y, z such that (x,y)\in f and (x,z)\in f, we have y=z. Instead of (x,y)\in f, we write f(x)=y.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Naive Set Theory

fr:title.text: Relations and functions in naive set theory

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Relations and functions in naive set theory
Relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We can define a Relation broadly is a set R such that for all objects r\in R there exists objects x and y such that r=(x,y). In other words, a relation is a set which consists of ordered pairs.
When X and Y are sets, a Relation of X and Y is a subset R\subseteq X\times Y.
We will speak of a "Relation of X" when referring to a subset R\subseteq X\times X.

If R is a relation and (x,y)\in R, then we will frequently abuse notation and write x\;R\;y. Usually instead of R, for particular relations we use \sim , \approx , \cong , \equiv , \lt , or other notation which is more aesthetically pleasing.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Domain of a relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a relation. We define the Domain of R to be the set \mathop {\textrm {dom}}\nolimits (R)=\{x\mid \exists y\ldotp (x,y)\in R\}.
When R is a relation of X and Y, we see \mathop {\textrm {dom}}\nolimits (R)\subseteq X.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Range of a relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a relation. We define the Range of R to be the set \mathop {\textrm {ran}}\nolimits (R)=\{y\mid \exists x\ldotp (x,y)\in R\}.
When R is a relation of X and Y, we see \mathop {\textrm {ran}}\nolimits (R)\subseteq Y.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field of a relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7
MML relat_1:def 6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a relation. We define the Field of R is just \mathop {\textrm {dom}}\nolimits (R)\cup \mathop {\textrm {ran}}\nolimits (R).
Observe when R is a relation of X and Y, the field F of R is a subset F\subseteq X\cup Y.
Let R be a relation. We define the Inverse of R to be the relation R^{-1}=\{(y,x)\mid (x,y)\in R\}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Reflexive relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7
MML relat_2:def 9

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a relation, let F be its field. We say R is Reflexive if for each x\in F we have (x,x)\in R.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Symmetric relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7
MML relat_2:def 11

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a relation, let F be its field. We say R is Symmetric if for all x\in F and y\in F, if (x,y)\in R, then (y,x)\in R.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Transitive relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7
MML relat_2:def 16

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a relation, let F be its field. We say R is Transitive if for all x\in F, y\in F, and z\in F, if (x,y)\in R and (y,z)\in R, then (x,z)\in R.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equivalence relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7
MML eqrel_1:def

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set. We define an Equivalence Relation of X to be a reflexive symmetric transitive relation of X.
For example, R=\{(x,x)\mid x\in X\} is always an equivalence relation of X which describes equality of elements of X.
More generally, an equivalence relation is a generalization of equality. Consequently, it is common to use notation like \sim , \approx , \equiv , \cong for equivalence relations.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equivalence class
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7
MML eqrel_1:def

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let x\in X, and let R be an equivalence relation of X. We define the Equivalence Class of x with respect to R is the set [x]_{R}=\{y\in X\mid (x,y)\in R\} consisting of all elements equivalent to x under R.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composing relations
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7
MML relat_1:def 8

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let P and R be relations. We define their Composition to be the relation denoted PR or R\circ P such that for all objects x and z we have (x,z)\in PR iff there exists an object y such that (x,y)\in P and (y,z)\in R.
The PR notation means xPRz iff there exists a y such that xPyRz.
The R\circ P notation is useful for working with functions.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composing relations is associative
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML relat_1:th36

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R_{1}, R_{2}, R_{3} be relations. Then (R_{1}\circ R_{2})\circ R_{3}=R_{1}\circ (R_{2}\circ R_{3}).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Function
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.8

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let X and Y be sets. We define a Function from X to Y to be a relation of X and Y denoted f\colon X\to Y such that:
Total: \mathop {\textrm {dom}}\nolimits (f)=X, and
Function-like: for all objects x, y, z such that (x,y)\in f and (x,z)\in f, we have y=z. Instead of (x,y)\in f, we write f(x)=y.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set of all functions
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.8
MML funct_2:def 2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X and Y be sets. We denote the Set of all functions from X to Y as either Y^{X} or \hom (X,Y).
We see this really is a set, since a function is a subset of X\times Y, so the set of all functions is a subset of \mathcal {P}(X\times Y).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inclusion
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.8
MML funct_3:def

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a subset of Y. Then the Inclusion of X into Y is the function i\colon X\to Y defined by i(x)=x for all x\in X.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity function
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML relat_1:def 10

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set. We define the Identity Function of X to be the function \mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{X}\colon X\to X such that for all x\in X, \mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{X}(x)=x.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Restriction of a function
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.8
MML relat_1:def 11

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let g\colon Y\to Z be a function, let X\subseteq Y. We define the Restriction of g to X to be the function g|_{X}\colon X\to Z such that for all x\in X, g|_{X}(x)=g(x).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Projection of Cartesian product
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.8

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X and Y be sets. We define the Projection Functions \pi _{1}\colon X\times Y\to X and \pi _{2}\colon X\times Y\to Y by \pi _{1}(x,y)=x and \pi _{2}(x,y)=y for all x\in X and y\in Y.
Let f\colon X\to Y and g\colon Y\to Z be functions. Then the Composition of f followed by g is the function g\circ f\colon X\to Z defined by (g\circ f)(x)=g(f(x)) for all x\in X.
Observe this is just the Composing relations.
Let f\colon W\to X, g\colon X\to Y, h\colon Y\to Z be functions. Then h\circ (g\circ f)=(h\circ g)\circ f.
This follows from composing relations is associative.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Preimage of a function
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.10

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon X\to Y be a function, let B\subseteq Y. We define the Preimage of B under f to be the set f^{-1}(A)=\{x\in X\mid f(x)\in B\}.
This is sometimes denoted f^{*}(B) to avoid confusing the preimage with the inverse function of f. This allows us to interpret f^{*}\colon \mathcal {P}(Y)\to \mathcal {P}(X) without ambiguity.
Let X and Y be sets, let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We define the Image (or Range) of f to be the subset \mathop {\textrm {ran}}\nolimits (f)=f(X)=\{f(x)\in Y\mid x\in X\}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct image of a function
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.10

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. Let A\subseteq X. We define the Direct Image of A under f to be the set f(A)=\{f(x)\in Y\mid x\in A\}.
We sometimes use the notation f_{*}(A) for the direct image of A under f, so we can describe a function f_{*}\colon \mathcal {P}(X)\to \mathcal {P}(Y).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon X\to Y be a function, let L\subseteq X and R\subseteq X be subsets. Then the following all hold:
Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We say f is Surjective (or that it's a surjection) if for each y\in Y there is at least one x\in X such that f(x)=y.
In other words, the image of f is the codomain of f. Or more vividly, f "covers" all of Y.
Let f\colon X\to Y be an Surjective function. Then there exists a function g\colon Y\to X such that f\circ g=\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{Y}.
We call such a g a Right Inverse of f.
Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We say f is injective (or that it's a injection) if for all x_{1},x_{2}\in X such that f(x_{1})=f(x_{2}) we have x_{1}=x_{2}.
Equivalently, if f(x_{1})\neq f(x_{2}), then x_{1}\neq x_{2}.
So no two distinct elements of X are mapped to the same element under f.

fr:title.text: Injective functions have a left inverse function

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Injective functions have a left inverse function

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon X\to Y be an Injective function. Then there exists a function g\colon Y\to X such that g\circ f=\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{X}.
We call such a g a Left Inverse of f.
We say a function f\colon X\to Y is Bijective (or say f is a bijection) if f is both injective and surjective.
This means for each y\in Y, there exists a unique x\in X such that f(x)=y.

Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We call a function g\colon Y\to X the Inverse of f if f\circ g=\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{Y} and g\circ f=\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{X}. When such a g exists, we denote it by f^{-1}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Bijective functions have unique inverse
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML funct_1:def 5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon X\to Y be an Bijective function. Then there exists a function g\colon Y\to X such that f\circ g=\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{Y} and g\circ f=\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{X}. Moreover this function g is unique.
We call such a g the Inverse of f, and we usually denote it by f^{-1}=g.
We see that if (x,y)\in f, then (y,x)\in g.
Let I be a set. A Family of Sets Indexed by I is a function-like set \mathcal {F} such that \mathop {\textrm {dom}}\nolimits (\mathcal {F})=I.
We usually write \mathcal {F}=\{F_{i}\}_{i\in I}.

fr:title.text: Unions and intersections of indexed families of sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Unions and intersections of indexed families of sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We adopt the notation that, when I is an indexing and \mathcal {F}=\{F_{i}\}_{i\in I} is an Indexed family of sets, we write \bigcup _{i\in I}F_{i}:=\bigcup \mathcal {F} and \bigcap _{i\in I}F_{i}:=\bigcap \mathcal {F}. When I=\mathbb {N} we write \bigcup _{i=1}^{\infty }F_{i}:=\bigcup \mathcal {F} and \bigcap _{i=1}^{\infty }F_{i}:=\bigcap \mathcal {F}. Similarly, for finite unions ranging over specific indices in an ordered indexing set, we use the lower and upper limits to demarcate the range of the subfamily of sets.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Product of family of sets
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: MML card_3:def 5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let I be a set, let \mathcal {F}=\{F_{i}\}_{i\in I} be an Indexed family of sets indexed by I. We define the Product of \{F_{i}\}_{i\in I} to be the set \prod \mathcal {F}=\prod _{i\in I}F_{i} such that for any object x, we have x\in \prod _{i\in I} if and only if x if function-like and \mathop {\textrm {dom}}\nolimits (x)=\mathop {\textrm {dom}}\nolimits (\mathcal {F}) and for each i\in I we have x_{i}\in F_{i}.

Well-definedness: We should prove this is well-defined, but we see this is equivalent to: \prod _{i\in I}F_{i}=\{x\in \hom (I,\bigcup _{i\in I}F_{i})\mid \forall i\in I\ldotp x(i)\in F_{i}\}. This is obvious a well-defined set using Set builder notation.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We see that when I=\{0,1\}, this is bijective (but not equal) to F_{0}\times F_{1}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cosets of stabilizer are bijective with the orbits
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Artin's Algebra Proposition 6.8.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We need to show \overline {f} is a well-defined Function. We see if aG_{x}=bG_{x}, then a^{-1}b\in G_{x} and by definition of the Stabilizer we see a^{-1}b\cdot x=x and therefore a\cdot x=b\cdot x. Therefore this is a well-defined function.
Reading this argument backwards, we establish \overline {f} is injective.
Since \overline {f} maps gG_{x} to g\cdot x, and g\cdot x can be an arbitrary element of G\cdot x, this means \overline {f} is surjective. Hence \overline {f} is bijective.
